statement.p:
Suppose that T is the matrix transformation defined by the matrix A and S is the matrix transformation defined by B where
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 3 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ -1 \amp 3 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right], \qquad B = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] .
If T:\real^n\to\real^m, what are the values of m and n? What values of m and n are appropriate for the transformation S?
Evaluate T\left(\threevec{1}{-3}{2}\right).
Evaluate S\left(\threevec{-2}{2}{1}\right).
Evaluate S\circ T\left(\threevec{1}{-3}{2}\right).
Find the matrix C that defines the matrix transformation S\circ T.

li.p: Since A is a 3\times3 matrix, we have T:\real^3\to\real^3. Since B is a 2\times3 matrix, we have S:\real^3\to\real^2.

statement.p:
This problem concerns the identification of matrix transformations, about which more will be said in the next section.
Check that the following function T:\real^3\to\real^2 is a matrix transformation by finding a matrix A such that T(\xvec) = A\xvec.
T\left(\threevec{x_1}{x_2}{x_3}\right) = \left[\begin{array}{c} 3x_1 - x_2 + 4x_3 \\ 5x_2 - x_3 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Explain why
T\left(\threevec{x_1}{x_2}{x_3}\right) = \left[\begin{array}{c} 3x_1^4 - x_2 + 4x_3 \\ 5x_2 - x_3 \\ \end{array}\right] is not a matrix transformation.

li.p: Because the first component has the term 3x_1^4, there is no matrix such that T(\xvec) = A\xvec.
Because the first component has the term 3x_1^4.

statement.p:
Suppose that the matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 3 \amp 1 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 5 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right]
defines the matrix transformation T:\real^3\to\real^3.
Describe the vectors \xvec that satisfy T(\xvec) = \zerovec.
Describe the vectors \xvec that satisfy T(\xvec) = \threevec{-8}{9}{2}.
Describe the vectors \xvec that satisfy T(\xvec) = \threevec{-8}{2}{-4}.

li.p: We have T(\xvec) = A\xvec = \zerovec. The reduced row echelon form of A is A \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]. Therefore, the solutions have the form \xvec=x_3\threevec{2}{-1}{1}.

statement.p: Suppose T:\real^3\to\real^2 is a matrix transformation with T(\evec_j) = \vvec_j where \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 are as shown in .

description.p: The linear transformation T:\real^3\to\real^2 produces the three vectors \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3. First, we have \vvec_1 = T\left(\threevec100\right)=\twovec21. Then \vvec_2 = T\left(\threevec010\right)=\twovec{-1}1, and finally \vvec_3 = T\left(\threevec001\right)=\twovec{-1}{-2}.

li.p: Find all the vectors \xvec such that T(\xvec) = \zerovec.

statement.p:
In and , we wrote matrix transformations in terms of the components of T(\xvec). This exercise makes use of that form.
Let's return to the example in concerning the company that operates two bakeries. We used a matrix transformation with input \xvec, which recorded the amount of time the two bakeries operated, and output T(\xvec), the number of cakes, doughnuts, and eclairs produced. The associated matrix is A=\begin{bmatrix} 10 \amp 20 \\ 50 \amp 30 \\ 30 \amp 30 \\ \end{bmatrix} .
If \xvec=\twovec{x_1}{x_2}, write the output T(\xvec) as a three-dimensional vector in terms of x_1 and x_2.
If Bakery 1 operates for x_1 hours and Bakery 2 for x_2 hours, how many cakes are produced?
Explain how you may have discovered this expression by considering the rates at which the two locations make cakes.
Suppose that a bicycle sharing program has two locations P and Q. Bicycles are rented from some location in the morning and returned to a location in the evening. Suppose that
60% of bicycles that begin at P in the morning are returned to P in the evening while the other 40% are returned to Q.
30% of bicycles that begin at Q are returned to Q and the other 70% are returned to P.
If x_1 is the number of bicycles at location P and x_2 the number at Q in the morning, write an expression for the number of bicycles at P in the evening.
Write an expression for the number of bicycles at Q in the evening.
Write an expression for T\left(\twovec{x_1}{x_2}\right), the vector that describs the distribution of bicycles in the evening.
Use this expression to identify the matrix A associated to the matrix transformation T.

li.p: The number of cakes produced is 10x_1 + 20x_2.

This is consistent with the given information because Bakery 1 produces cakes at the rate of 10 cakes per hour so the number of cakes it produces is 10x_1. In the same way, the number of cakes produced by Bakery 2 is 20x_2 giving a total of 10x_1 + 20x_2.

Of the bicycles that begin at P, 60% of them end up at P. Therefore 0.6x_1 is the number of bicycles that begin at P and end at P. Similarly, 70% of the bicycles that begin at Q end up at P so this number is 0.7x_2. Therefore, the total number of bicycles that end up at P is
0.6x_1 + 0.7x_2.

In the same way, the number of bicycles that end up at Q is
0.4x_1 + 0.3x_2.
Bakery 1 makes 10 cakes per hour and Bakery 2 makes 20.

statement.p:
Determine whether the following statements are true or false and provide a justification for your response.
A matrix transformation T:\real^4\to\real^5 is defined by T(\xvec) = A\xvec where A is a 4\times5 matrix.
If T:\real^3\to\real^2 is a matrix transformation, then there are infinitely many vectors \xvec such that T(\xvec) = \zerovec.
If T:\real^2\to\real^3 is a matrix transformation, then it is possible that every equation T(\xvec) = \bvec has a solution for every vector \bvec.
If T:\real^n\to\real^m is a matrix transformation, then the equation T(\xvec) = \zerovec always has a solution.

li.p: False. The dimensions of A are 5\times4.
True. The dimensions of A are 2\times3 so there must be a column without a pivot position.
False. The dimensions of A are 3\times2 so there must be a row without a pivot position.
True. The vector \xvec=\zerovec is always a solution.

statement.p:
Suppose that a company has three plants, called Plants 1, 2, and 3, that produce milk M and yogurt Y. For every hour of operation,
Plant 1 produces 20 units of milk and 15 units of yogurt.
Plant 2 produces 30 units of milk and 5 units of yogurt.
Plant 3 produces 0 units of milk and 40 units of yogurt.
Suppose that x_1, x_2, and x_3 record the amounts of time that the three plants are operated and that M and Y record the amount of milk and yogurt produced. If we write \xvec=\threevec{x_1}{x_2}{x_3} and \yvec = \twovec{M}{Y}, find the matrix A that defines the matrix transformation T(\xvec) = \yvec.
Furthermore, suppose that producing each unit of
milk requires 5 units of electricity and 8 units of labor.
yogurt requires 6 units of electricity and 10 units of labor.
If we write the vector \zvec = \twovec{E}{L} to record the required amounts of electricity E and labor L, find the matrix B that defines the matrix transformation S(\yvec) = \zvec.
If \xvec = \threevec{30}{20}{10} describes the amounts of time that the three plants are operated, how much milk and yogurt is produced? How much electricity and labor are required?
Find the matrix C that describes the matrix transformation R(\xvec)=\zvec that gives the required amounts of electricity and labor when the each plants is operated an amount of time given by the vector \xvec.

li.p: The first column of the matrix is T\left(\threevec{1}{0}{0}\right)=\twovec{20}{15}. This shows us that the matrix is A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 20 \amp 30 \amp 0 \\ 15 \amp 5 \amp 40 \\ \end{array}\right].
In the same way, the matrix is B = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 5 \amp 6 \\ 8 \amp 10 \\ \end{array}\right].

statement.p:
Suppose that T:\real^2\to\real^2 is a matrix transformation and that
T\left(\twovec{1}{1}\right) = \twovec{3}{-2}, \qquad T\left(\twovec{-1}{1}\right) = \twovec{1}{2} .
Find the vector T\left(\twovec{1}{0}\right).
Find the matrix A that defines T.
Find the vector T\left(\twovec{4}{-5}\right).

Suppose that two species P and Q interact with one another and that we measure their populations every month. We record their populations in a state vector \xvec = \twovec{p}{q}, where p and q are the populations of P and Q, respectively. We observe that there is a matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.8 \amp 0.3 \\ 0.7 \amp 1.2 \\ \end{array}\right]
such that the matrix transformation T(\xvec)=A\xvec is the transition function describing how the state vector evolves from month to month. We also observe that, at the beginning of July, the populations are described by the state vector \xvec=\twovec{1}{2}.
What will the populations be at the beginning of August?
What were the populations at the beginning of June?
What will the populations be at the beginning of December?
What will the populations be at the beginning of July in the following year?

solution.p:
The initial state is the vector \xvec_0=\twovec{1}{2}.
At the beginning of August, we have \xvec_1 = A\xvec_0 = \twovec{1.4}{3.1}.
At the beginning of June, we have A\xvec_{-1} = \xvec_0. Solving this equation gives \xvec_{-1}=\twovec{0.8}{1.2}.
At the beginning of December, we have \xvec_5=A^5\xvec_0 = \twovec{6.8}{15.9}.
At the beginning of July in the following year, we have \xvec_{12} = A^{12}\xvec_0 = \twovec{116.8}{272.5}.

statement.p:
Students in a school are sometimes absent due to an illness. Suppose that
95% of the students who attend school will attend school the next day.
50% of the students who are absent one day will be absent the next day.
We will record the number of present students p and the number of absent students a in a state vector \xvec=\twovec{p}{a} and note that that state vector evolves from one day to the next according to the transition function T:\real^2\to\real^2. On Tuesday, the state vector is \xvec=\ctwovec{1700}{100}.
Suppose we initially have 1000 students who are present and none absent. Find T\left(\ctwovec{1000}{0}\right).
Suppose we initially have 1000 students who are absent and none present. Find T\left(\ctwovec{0}{1000}\right).
Use the results of parts a and b to find the matrix A that defines the matrix transformation T.
If \xvec=\ctwovec{1700}{100} on Tuesday, how are the students distributed on Wednesday?
How many students were present on Monday?
How many students are present on the following Tuesday?
What happens to the number of students who are present after a very long time?

li.p: T(\xvec) = A\xvec = \twovec{1665}{135} meaning that 1665 students are present and 135 are absent.
We want to solve the equation T(\xvec) = A\xvec=\twovec{1700}{100}, which gives \xvec = \twovec{1778}{22}. There were 1778 students present on Monday.
The following Tuesday, the state will be described by the vector A^7\twovec{1700}{100} = \twovec{1636}{163}. This means that there were 1636 students present the following Tuesday.
If we compute A^k\twovec{1700}{100} for some large powers k, we find that there are about 1636 students present every day after a very long time.
There are 1665 students present and 135 absent.
